questions.text: A pap smear taken from a patient revealed hyperchromatic nuclei, irregular nuclear borders, and a low maturation index involving the whole thickness but did not breach the basement membrane. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Dysplasia

Explanation:

  • The findings described in the pap smear hyperchromatic nuclei, irregular nuclear borders, and low maturation index are characteristic of dysplasia, a pre-cancerous condition.
  • Dysplasia is abnormal cell growth and differentiation, often seen in the epithelial layer, without penetration through the basement membrane.
  • This is reversible in the early stages (may become irreversible if the entire epithelium is involved).

 

Carcinoma (Option B) refers to invasive cancer where the abnormal cells have breached the basement membrane and spread beyond the epithelial layer. The description clearly states that the basement membrane is intact, ruling out carcinoma.

Metaplasia (Option C) is the replacement of one type of cell with another, often occurring in response to tissue damage, repair, chronic irritation, or regeneration. It does not explain the nuclear changes (hyperchromasia and irregularity) seen in the pap smear.

Hyperplasia (Option D) is an increase in the number of cells in a tissue, typically in response to a stimulus. It does not usually involve abnormal nuclear features like hyperchromasia and irregular borders, which are more indicative of dysplasia.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman presents with lower abdominal discomfort. The surgical image is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Mature cystic teratoma

Explanation:

  • Teratomas are tumours that originate from all three germ layers (ectoderm, mesoderm, and endoderm) and are commonly found in the ovaries.
  • They are often seen in young women and can contain a variety of tissue types, such as hair, teeth, and muscle, which reflects their origin from all three germ layers.

Mature teratoma

  • Mature teratomas, or dermoid cysts, are common benign ovarian tumours found in young women. They are bilateral in 10-15% of cases.
  • They contain tissues from all three germ layers, including skin, hair, and teeth, and can rarely undergo malignant transformation to squamous cell carcinoma.
  • Grossly, they are unilocular cysts with a thin wall and hair; microscopically, they have stratified squamous epithelium and sebaceous glands.

Immature teratoma: (Option B)

  • Bulky, solid ovarian tumours that contain immature neuroepithelium, cartilage, bone, and muscle, with areas of necrosis and haemorrhage.
  • They grow rapidly, often spreading beyond the ovary.
  • They are seen in young females and have a high risk of malignancy.
  • They have small, round blue cells (Immature neural components).

Monodermal teratoma:

  • Monodermal teratomas consist predominantly of a single type of tissue, such as thyroid tissue in struma ovarii or neuroendocrine cells in carcinoid tumours. They lack immature or embryonic-like tissues and typically do not have a high risk of malignancy.

Serous cystadenoma (Option A):

  • It is the most common ovarian epithelial tumor, usually seen in older women. It is unilocular, bilateral in >50% and is mostly malignant. The characteristic histologic feature is the presence of psamomma bodies (seen in 40-45%) which is composed of concentric rings of lamellar calcifications.

Endometrioma (Option D): “chocolate cyst” of endometriosis, filled with old blood, not sebaceous material or calcified teeth.

questions.text: Which of the following is an incorrect gene-disease association?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) TP53 - Mucosal Neuroma

Explanation:

  • TP53 is not associated with mucosal neuroma.

Gene

Associated tumours

BRCA1

Breast, ovarian, fallopian tube, pancreas, and prostate.

BRCA2 (Option D ruled out)

Breast, ovarian, pancreas, and prostate.

Associated with male breast cancer.

TP53 (Option C)

Breast, sarcoma, leukaemia, and brain tumours.

PTEN (Option B ruled out)

Breast, thyroid, and endometrium.

STK11 (Option A ruled out)

Breast, ovarian, colon, and pancreas.

CDH1

Breast, gastric signet ring cell carcinoma, and colon.

PALPB2

Breast, pancreas, and prostate.

CHEK2

Prostate, thyroid, colon, and kidney.

questions.text: The type of cancer that rarely spreads through the lymphatic system is:
questions.solution:
Correct Option C. 

  • Basal cell carcinoma is the most common form of skin cancer, typically originating in the basal cells of the skin. BCC is usually localized to the site of origin and tends to grow slowly. While it can invade and damage nearby tissues if left untreated, it has a low potential for metastasis. BCC rarely spreads to lymph nodes or distant organs through the lymphatic or bloodstream routes, making it less likely to disseminate through the lymphatic system compared to SCC, MCC, or malignant melanoma.

Incorrect Option: 

Option A. Squamous cell carcinoma (SCC):

  • Squamous cell carcinoma is a type of skin cancer that arises from squamous cells, which are flat cells found in the outermost layer of the skin. SCC can occur in various areas of the body, including the skin, lips, mouth, throat, esophagus, lungs, and other internal organs. It has the potential to metastasize and spread to nearby lymph nodes and distant sites, making it more likely to spread through the lymphatic route compared to basal cell carcinoma.

Option B. Merkel cell carcinoma (MCC):

  • Merkel cell carcinoma is a rare and aggressive type of skin cancer that develops from Merkel cells, which are involved in the sensation of touch. MCC typically occurs on sun-exposed areas of the skin, such as the head, neck, and arms. It has a higher tendency to spread through the lymphatic system, involving nearby lymph nodes and potentially metastasizing to distant sites.

Option D. Malignant melanoma:

  • Malignant melanoma is a type of skin cancer that arises from melanocytes, the pigment-producing cells of the skin. It is known for its ability to metastasize and spread rapidly. Malignant melanoma has a high potential to invade lymphatic vessels and lymph nodes, leading to lymphatic metastasis. It can also spread through the bloodstream to distant organs, such as the liver, lungs, brain, and bones. Early detection and treatment are crucial for improving outcomes in cases of malignant melanoma.

questions.text: Which of the following shows breast necrosis and calcification?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Comedo subtype of DCIS:

  • The comedo subtype of DCIS is characterized by high-grade tumor cells with central necrosis.
  • The necrotic cells often calcify, leading to the presence of calcifications detectable on mammography.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Cribriform subtype of DCIS: The cribriform subtype of DCIS features cells that form gland-like structures or "cribriform" patterns within the ducts.

Option C - Colloid carcinoma:

  • Colloid carcinoma is characterized by the production of large amounts of extracellular mucin.
  • It typically appears as a gelatinous mass.

Option D - Lobular carcinoma in situ: Lobular carcinoma in situ involves the proliferation of small, uniform cells that fill the lobules of the breast.

questions.text: p53 regulates which phase of cell cycle?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - G1S:

  • p53 is a tumor suppressor protein that plays a crucial role in preventing the proliferation of cells with damaged DNA.
  • It acts as a transcription factor that can induce the expression of genes involved in cell cycle arrest, DNA repair, and apoptosis.
  • The G1S checkpoint is a critical control point where the cell assesses whether it is ready to enter the S phase.
  • If DNA damage is detected, p53 can induce the expression of p21, a cyclin-dependent kinase (CDK) inhibitor.
  • p21 binds to and inhibits the activity of the cyclin-CDK complexes, thereby preventing the cell from progressing from G1 to S phase.

Incorrect Options: Options B, C, and D are incorrect.

Option C - G2M: Although p53 can influence the G2M checkpoint indirectly by allowing repair of DNA before mitosis, its primary role remains at the G1S transition.

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy was brought by his parents with concerns about being increasingly clumsy for the past 6 months. On examination, there is leukocoria with an absence of the red reflex in the left eye. As further workup reveals a tumour, the eye is enucleated, and the microscopic appearance is as shown in the image. Molecular analysis of the tumour indicates a loss of cell cycle control in the tumour cells. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Retinoblastoma

Explanation:

  • The child presents with leukocoria (white pupillary reflex) and progressive clumsiness, raising suspicion for an intraocular malignancy. The absence of a red reflex suggests an opaque mass within the eye, which is highly indicative of retinoblastoma, the most common primary intraocular malignancy in children.
  • Age of Presentation: Usually before 3 years, with non-familial cases diagnosed by 1 year.
  • Clinical Features:
    • Leukocoria (most common presenting sign)
    • Strabismus (misaligned eyes) due to loss of vision
    • Proptosis in advanced cases
    • Orbital invasion and metastasis in late stages.
  • Histopathology:
    • Small round blue cells are characteristic of primitive neuroectodermal tumours.
    • Anastomosing areas of necrosis
    • Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes (well-differentiated tumours)
  • Molecular Pathogenesis:
    • RB1 gene mutation on chromosome 13q14, leading to loss of cell cycle control.
    • Loss of both alleles of RB1 leads to uncontrolled retinal cell proliferation.

 

Wilms tumour (Option A), a nephroblastoma, typically presents with an abdominal mass, hematuria, and hypertension and histologically shows a triphasic pattern with blastemal, stromal, and epithelial components.

Ependymoma (Option C) arises in the fourth ventricle or spinal cord, leading to obstructive hydrocephalus, and shows perivascular pseudorosettes and true rosettes on histology.

PA

 

Neuroblastoma (Option D), a neural crest tumour usually originating in the adrenal gland or sympathetic chain, presents with an abdominal mass, periorbital ecchymoses ("raccoon eyes"), and opsoclonus-myoclonus syndrome, with histology showing Homer-Wright rosettes and immunohistochemical positivity for chromogranin, synaptophysin, and neuron-specific enolase (NSE).

questions.text: Which of the following enzymes is responsible for the immortality of cancer cells?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Telomerase

Explanation:

  • Telomerase maintains telomere length, preventing chromosome degradation.
  • Telomere shortening occurs with each cell division, contributing to cellular ageing and death.
  • However, telomerase extends telomeres, enabling indefinite division. In cancer cells, its overexpression promotes uncontrolled proliferation and immortality.

 

Incorrect Options:

Topoisomerase (Option B) is responsible for manipulating the structure of DNA by inducing and resolving DNA strand breaks.

Helicase (Option C) unwinds the DNA double helix, allowing other enzymes to access and replicate the DNA.

RNA polymerase (Option D) synthesises RNA from a DNA template during transcription, essential for gene expression and protein synthesis. While its dysregulation can occur in cancer, it is not directly linked to cancer cell immortality.

questions.text:
The lining epithelium of the respiratory tract of a middle-aged man who is a chronic smoker shows a change from columnar to stratified squamous epithelium, as depicted in the image below. The change is called what?



{{caption_text}}
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Metaplasia

Explanation:

  • Metaplasia refers to the reversible change in which one type of adult cell is replaced by another type. In this case, the columnar epithelium of the respiratory tract is replaced by stratified squamous epithelium, often as a result of chronic irritation, such as smoking.

Metaplasia:

  • Metaplasia is a reversible change in which another cell type replaces one differentiated cell type (epithelial or mesenchymal).
  • Metaplasia is a change in the phenotype of differentiated cells, often in response to chronic irritation that makes cells better able to withstand stress; usually induced by altered differentiation pathway of tissue stem cells, may result in reduced functions or increased propensity for malignant transformation.
  • Barrett's oesophagus is characterised by the replacement of the normal squamous epithelium of the lower oesophagus with columnar epithelium containing goblet cells & is considered an adaptive response to chronic exposure to gastric acid and bile reflux in the setting of GERD.
  • The presence of Barrett's oesophagus increases the risk of developing oesophagal adenocarcinoma.
  • Transformation of columnar epithelium to squamous epithelium: In the respiratory tract, in response to chronic irritation, such as smoking, the columnar epithelium undergoes metaplasia to squamous epithelium, leading to a condition known as squamous metaplasia.
  • Conversion of glandular epithelium to squamous epithelium: This type of metaplasia can be seen in the cervix, where the normal glandular epithelium undergoes metaplasia to the squamous epithelium in response to chronic inflammation or irritation, leading to a condition known as cervical squamous metaplasia.
  • Substitution of mesenchymal cells with epithelial cells: An example of this can be seen in osseous metaplasia, where mesenchymal cells differentiate into bone-forming osteoblasts, leading to the formation of ectopic bone within soft tissues.

Incorrect Options:

Dysplasia (Option A) refers to the abnormal development or growth of cells or tissues. It is characterised by disordered cell structures and is considered a precursor to cancer.

Hypertrophy (Option B) is the increase in the size of cells, leading to the enlargement of an organ or tissue. It typically occurs in response to increased functional demand or external stimulation.

Atrophy (Option C) is the reduction in the size or number of cells, leading to the shrinkage of an organ or tissue. It can result from factors such as disuse, loss of nerve supply, or inadequate blood flow.

questions.text: What is the fixation technique employed to examine fat in histopathology?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Frozen section

Explanation:

  • The frozen section is done for the fixation of fats. It is a technique used to examine tissue samples quickly by freezing them and then cutting them into thin slices for immediate microscopic examination.
  • This method is often preferred for fat tissue examination because it prevents the loss of lipid content, which can be affected by formalin fixation.

 

 

  • Advantages:
    • It provides rapid results & ideal for intraoperative consultations (e.g., determining malignancy during surgery).
    • It is essential for preserving certain tissue components like fat, enzymes, and lipids that might be damaged by formalin fixation.

 

Fixatives & uses:

Technique / Tissue

Fixative

Electron microscopy

Glutaraldehyde

Bone marrow (Trephine biopsy)

Zenker’s fluid

GI biopsy

Bouin’s fluid

Brain

Formalin ammonium chloride

Adrenal biopsy

Orth’s fluid

Pap smear

Ethanol

 

IHC (Immunohistochemistry) (Option A) is used to detect specific proteins or antigens in tissue sections using targeted antibodies. Although IHC can identify markers associated with fat cells, it is not a fixation method for examining fat.

Liquid paraffin (Option C) is not a fixation agent but a mounting medium applied to tissue sections on slides. It provides optical clarity and preserves the specimen but does not fix or preserve fat specifically.

Formalin fixation (Option D) is a commonly used method to preserve tissue samples in histopathology. While it preserves the general structure of tissues, it is not ideal for preserving fat. Formalin can cause partial extraction of fat, leading to the loss of fat droplets and artefacts during tissue processing.

questions.text: A woman was diagnosed with metastatic liver adenocarcinoma with CK7-, CK20+, and CDX1+ immunohistochemistry (IHC) markers. Which of the following is the most likely primary site of origin for this metastasis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Colon carcinoma

Explanation:

  • Colon carcinoma typically shows a CK7- and CK20+ pattern, and CDX1 is a transcription factor often expressed in the intestinal epithelium, further supporting a colon origin for the metastasis.

CK7:

  • Positive in carcinomas from the lung, breast, ovary, and pancreas.
  • Negative in most gastrointestinal tract carcinomas, including those originating from the colon.

CK20:

  • Positive in colorectal and urothelial carcinomas.
  • Negative in carcinomas of the lung, breast, and ovary.

CDX1:

  • Positive in adenocarcinomas of the gastrointestinal tract, particularly colorectal carcinomas.
  • Negative in most non-gastrointestinal carcinomas, such as those from the breast, lung, ovary, and pancreas.

Tumor Type

CK7

CK20

CDX1

Colon carcinoma

-

+

+

Breast carcinoma

+

-

-

Pancreatic carcinoma

+

+

-

Ovarian carcinoma

+

-

-

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of MEN type II syndrome?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Pancreatic adenoma

 

Explanation:

Pancreatic adenoma is a part of MEN1 syndrome, not MEN2.

 

Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia (MEN) is a group of genetic syndromes (Autosomal dominant) characterised by the development of tumours in multiple endocrine glands.

  • Diagnostic criteria for MEN:
    • Clinical features of 2 or more associated tumours
    • Notable Family history
    • Confirmation by genetic analysis.

 

Types of Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia
 

MEN Type I

MEN Type II

MEN Type III

MEN Type IV

Cause
  • Defect of chromosome 11q13 causing MEN 1 gene mutation
  • Also called Wermer’s syndrome
  • Defect of chr.10 leading to mutation of RET gene
  • Also called Sipple’s syndrome

Also called MEN II B, it is a variant of Type 2 MEN

Defect of chr.12 causing CDKN1B gene

Tumors

Included

Parathyroid adenoma

(most common)

  • It presents with primary hyperparathyroidism (↑ PTH and ↑ Ca)

Parathyroid adenoma (most common, and calcium can be normal)

Medullary carcinoma thyroid (most common)

(Option A)

Parathyroid adenoma (Presents as hypercalcemia)

Pancreatic adenoma

(Option D)

  • Presents as Gastrinoma or Zollinger-Ellison syndrome

Pheochromocytoma.

Pheochromocytoma (Most important criterion for both MEN 2 and MEN 3): Presents with elevated blood pressure.

Pituitary adenoma: Prolactinoma

Pituitary adenoma: Prolactinoma, causing amenorrhea and Infertility

Medullary thyroid carcinoma

  • Calcitonin is the tumor marker present

Reproductive tract tumors

  • Testicular tumors
  • Neuroendocrine tumor (Cervix)

Associated conditions
  • Angioﬁbroma
  • Collagenoma
  • Adrenocortical tumor
  • Carcinoid tumors/Argentaﬃnoma
  • Pheochromocytoma (only in 1%)
  • Congenital aganglionosis,
  • Hirschsprung disease
  • Marfanoid habitus

(Option B)

  • Medullated corneal nerve ﬁbers
  • Mucosal neuromas

(Option C)

  • Megacolon and Multiple diverticulae

Occasionally with

  • Renal tumor
  • Adrenal tumor

questions.text: A 65-year-old female patient is diagnosed with pure red cell aplasia and a mediastinal mass. Which of the following is a likely cause?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Thymoma

Explanation:

  • The diagnosis of pure red cell aplasia (PRCA) in this patient, coupled with a mediastinal mass, strongly suggests a thymoma, a tumor of the thymus gland, which is located in the anterior mediastinum.
  • It is often asymptomatic initially but can cause a range of paraneoplastic syndromes and is also associated with autoimmune diseases like myasthenia gravis.
  • One of the paraneoplastic syndromes associated with thymoma is PRCA.
  • In PRCA, red blood cell production in the bone marrow is selectively failed, while white blood cells and platelets are usually unaffected. This leads to severe anemia in the absence of any abnormalities in other cell lines.

Thymoma

Clinical features
  • Mostly asymptomatic (small tumor), incidentally detected.
  • It may compress the trachea (dyspnea), esophagus (dysphagia), recurrent laryngeal nerve (dysphonia or hoarseness of voice), and superior vena cava (superior vena cava syndrome).

Investigations

CT scan
  • Investigation of choice
  • It is used to determine the extent of the disease.

 

Histology (definitive diagnosis)
  • Noninvasive thymomas: Medullary-type epithelial cells (elongated or spindle-shaped) or a mixture of medullary- and cortical-type epithelial cells (admixture of polygonal cortical-type epithelial cells and a denser infiltrate of thymocytes).

 

  • Invasive thymoma: Cytologically benign but locally invasive. The epithelial cells have abundant cytoplasm and rounded vesicular nuclei mixed with numerous thymocytes.
  • Cytokeratin (marker to distinguish thymoma from lymphoma; thymomas are positive for cytokeratin)

Non-Hodgkin lymphoma (Option B) can cause lymphadenopathy and mediastinal masses, but it is not associated with pure red cell aplasia.

Bronchogenic carcinoma (Option C) may cause mediastinal masses due to lymph node involvement or direct tumour extension, but it is not commonly associated with pure red cell aplasia.

Germ cell tumours (Option D) in the mediastinum can cause a mediastinal mass and are not typically linked with pure red cell aplasia.

questions.text: A patient with occupational exposure to benzene presents with repeated infections, easy fatigability, weight loss, and an evening rise in temperature. This occupational exposure will predispose him to which of the following cancers?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Leukemia

Explanation:

  • Occupational exposure to benzene is a well-established risk factor for the development of leukemia, particularly AML and ALL.
  • It is a known carcinogen that can cause damage to the bone marrow, leading to disruption of normal blood cell production, which can result in leukemia.
  • The clinical features in this case, such as repeated infections, fatigability, weight loss, and fever, also suggest a hematological malignancy like leukemia.

Risk of specific carcinomas related to specific exposure

Risk of carcinoma

Occupation exposure

Lungs (Option B ruled out)

Arsenic, beryllium, cadmium, chromium, Asbestosis, Silica, radon, Nickel, and aromatic hydrocarbon.

Bladder (Option C ruled out)

Benzidine, Auramine, Beta-naphthylamine, Para amino-diphenyl, Magenta.

Liver

Vinyl chloride, Arsenic.

Leukaemia

Benzene, ethylene oxide.

Skin (Option D ruled out)

Arsenic, ionising radiation, Polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons.

Scrotum

Polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons.

questions.text:
Which of the following is true?


	BRCA1 is an oncogene
	HER2neu is amplified only in a fraction of breast cancer
	EGFR+ is seen in non-small cell lung cancer
	N-MYC is a tumor suppressor gene
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) 2, 3

Explanation:

HER2/neu is amplified only in a fraction of breast cancer:

  • In breast cancer, amplification of the HER2 gene and overexpression of the HER2 protein can occur.
  • HER2 amplification is not observed in all breast cancers but only in a fraction of cases. (Statement 2)
  • Breast cancers that show HER2 amplification are referred to as HER2-positive breast cancers and can be targeted with specific therapies like trastuzumab.

EGFR is seen in non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC):

  • In non-small cell lung cancer, mutations or overexpression of the EGFR gene can occur. (Statement 3)
  • EGFR-targeted therapies, such as tyrosine kinase inhibitors, are used in the treatment of EGFR-positive NSCLC.

BRCA1 (Breast Cancer 1)

  • It is classified as a tumour suppressor gene. (Statement 1 ruled out)
  • Mutations increase the risk of cancers such as breast, ovarian, prostate, and pancreatic cancers and are inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern.

N-MYC

  • It is an oncogene. (Statement 4 ruled out)
  • It is associated with neuroblastoma (most common), small-cell lung cancer, and medulloblastoma.

questions.text: The human papillomavirus inactivates the Rb gene by which of the following proteins?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) E7

 

Explanation:

  • The human papillomavirus (HPV) inactivates the retinoblastoma (RB) gene primarily through the action of the E7 protein.
  • The E7 protein of high-risk HPV types, such as HPV-16 and HPV-18, promotes cell cycle progression by inactivating the retinoblastoma protein (p105Rb).
  • E7 binds to p105Rb, disrupting its interaction with the E2F transcription factor, which releases E2F to activate genes essential for cell cycle progression and DNA replication.
  • Consequently, the cell cycle becomes dysregulated, and uncontrolled cell proliferation can occur, a hallmark of HPV-associated cancers.
  • High-risk HPV types (HPV 16, 18): High-grade cervical dysplasia and invasive cancer.
  • Low-risk HPV types (HPV 6, 11): Genital warts (condyloma acuminatum and low-grade changes in cervical cells).

 

Oncogenic Activities of E6 Protein

(Option A ruled out)

Oncogenic Activities of E7 Protein

(Option B)
  • Binds to and promotes degradation of p53 → Impairs cell growth and apoptosis regulation.
  • Stimulates expression of TERT (telomerase reverse transcriptase) → Facilitates cellular immortalisation by maintaining telomere length.
  • Disrupts interaction between RB protein and E2F transcription factors
  • Inactivates CDK inhibitors (e.g., p21 and p27).
  • Activates cyclins A and E 

 

 

 

L1 (Option C) protein is the major capsid protein of HPV and plays a role in the virus particle assembly.

 

L2 (Option D) protein is a capsid protein of HPV, which assists in entering the viral DNA into the host cell during infection.

questions.text: Which of the following features does not distinguish between necrosis and apoptosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B -Association with underlying pathology:

  • Underlying pathological condition is not an important feature of differentiation between necrosis and apoptosis as necrosis and apoptosis both can be triggered by an underlying disease/ pathological condition.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Enzymatic degradation: In necrosis, cellular contents leak out and undergo enzymatic digestion, while in apoptosis, they're enclosed until released as apoptotic bodies, with the membrane intact until engulfed by phagocytic cells.

Option C - Lipid change: In apoptosis, inflammation is rare, while in necrosis, it's common due to released cellular contents triggering inflammation.

Option D - Intact membrane: In apoptosis, the cell membrane remains intact, whereas in necrosis, it is disrupted.

questions.text:
Match the following:

 


	
		
			
			A. Medullary thyroid cancer
			
			
			i. Catecholamine
			
		
		
			
			B. Hepatoblastoma
			
			
			ii. AFP
			
		
		
			
			C. Choriocarcinoma
			
			
			iii. Calcitonin
			
		
		
			
			D. Pheochromocytoma
			
			
			iv. Beta HCG
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) A-iii, B-ii, C-iv, D-i

 

Explanation:

 

Tumor marker

Associated conditions

Alpha-fetoprotein (AFP)

 
  • Hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC)
  • Hepatoblastoma
  • Yolk sac tumour (endodermal sinus tumour)
  • Nonseminomatous germ cell tumour of testis
  • ↑ AFP: abdominal wall defects, neural tube defects
  • ↓ AFP: associated with trisomy 21, 18, and 13 

β-HCG

 
  • Nonseminomatous testicular germ cell tumours (choriocarcinoma, embryonal cell carcinoma, mixed germ cell tumour, seminoma)
  • Ovarian cancer: choriocarcinoma (gestational trophoblastic disease)

Carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA)
  • Colorectal cancer
  • Pancreatic cancer
  • Breast cancer
  • Lung cancer (especially in non-small cell cancers)
  • Gastric cancer

Prostate-specific antigen (PSA)
  • Prostate cancer
  • Benign prostatic hyperplasia
  • Prostatitis

Calcitonin
  • Medullary thyroid cancer (both sporadic and associated with MEN 1 and MEN 2)

Alkaline phosphatase
  • Metastases to bone or liver
  • Paget disease of the bone

Catecholamine and metabolites
  • Pheochromocytoma and related tumors

Placental alkaline phosphatase
  • Seminoma

Lactate dehydrogenase
  • Ovarian cancer (dysgerminoma)
  • Testicular germ cell tumours (both seminoma and nonseminoma)
  • Lymphomas
  • Ewing's sarcoma

Neuron specific enolase (NSE)
  • Neuroendocrine tumors
  • Small cell lung cancer
  • Carcinoid tumour
  • Neuroblastoma

CA 19–9

  • Pancreatic adenocarcinoma
  • Colon cancer
  • Cholangiocarcinoma

CA 15–3 and CA 27–29
  • Breast cancer

CA 125

  • Ovarian carcinoma
  • Other gynecologic malignancies

S-100 protein (S100A) and (S100B)
  • Malignant melanoma

SMRP
  • Mesothelioma

questions.text: Epithelial-mesenchymal transition induced by which pair of transcription factors?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) SNAIL & TWIST

 

Explanation:

  • Epithelial-mesenchymal transition (EMT) is induced by the transcription factors SNAIL and TWIST.
  • It is a process where epithelial cells lose their polarity and cell-cell adhesion, gaining migratory and invasive properties to transform into mesenchymal stem cells, multipotent stromal cells.
  • t is hypothesized that E-cadherin (transmembrane glycoproteins that mediate the homotypic adhesion of epithelial cells) expression is transiently silenced through this process.
  • It is controlled by the transcription factors SNAIL and TWIST.
  • There is downregulation of epithelial markers (e.g., E-cadherin) and also upregulation of mesenchymal markers (e.g., vimentin and smooth muscle actin).

 

TF IIA & TF IIB (Option A) are essential general transcription factors that are key to the initiation of transcription by RNA polymerase II. TFIIA contributes to transcriptional regulation by modulating the initiation process and ensuring correct gene expression. TFIIB is responsible for forming the transcription initiation complex and facilitating the transition from initiation to elongation.

 

Cathepsin & MMP 8 (Matrix Metalloproteinase-8) (Option B) are enzymes that degrade proteins in the extracellular matrix, playing key roles in tissue remodelling and inflammation. Cathepsins aid in wound healing and immune responses but can contribute to cancer metastasis and inflammation. Elevated MMP-8 is linked to diseases like periodontal disease, arthritis, and cancer, where it contributes to tissue damage and remodelling.

 

STAT-5 & HIF-1 alpha (Option D) are transcription factors. STAT-5, activated by cytokine receptors, regulates cell survival, differentiation, and immune responses and is key in hematopoiesis and cancers like leukaemia. HIF-1 alpha responds to low oxygen levels, activating genes for angiogenesis, metabolism, and erythropoiesis, and plays a critical role in tumour growth in hypoxic environments.

questions.text: What is the tumour marker for a carcinoid tumour?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) 5-HIAA

Explanation:

  • The tumour marker for a Carcinoid Tumor is 5-HIAA (5-hydroxy indole acetic acid).
  • Carcinoids are derived from Argentaffin cells that secrete serotonin.
  • It is commonly caused by neuroendocrine tumours of the midgut that metastasise to the liver.
  • It is also seen with ovarian tumours or bronchial carcinoids. They secrete mediators like serotonin (5-hydroxytryptamine), kallikrein, bradykinin, histamine, and prostaglandins.
  • Clinical features:
    • Diarrhea and abdominal cramping
    • Flushing and pruritus due to histamine
    • Wheezing and dyspnea due to bronchospasm
    • Pellagra (diarrhoea, dermatitis, dementia)
    • Carcinoid heart disease: Tricuspid regurgitation leading to right heart failure
  • Diagnosis:
    • Elevated twenty-four-hour urine for 5-HIAA.
    • Elevated serum serotonin.
    • Elevated serum chromogranin A.
    • Octreoscan for localising the source.

Tumor marker

Associated conditions

Alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) (Option D ruled out)

 
  • Hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC)
  • Hepatoblastoma
  • Yolk sac tumour (endodermal sinus tumour)
  • Nonseminomatous germ cell tumour of testis
  • ↑ AFP: abdominal wall defects, neural tube defects
  • ↓ AFP: associated with trisomy 21, 18, and 13

β-HCG (Option A ruled out)

 
  • Nonseminomatous testicular germ cell tumours (choriocarcinoma, embryonal cell carcinoma, mixed germ cell tumour, seminoma)
  • Ovarian cancer: choriocarcinoma (gestational trophoblastic disease)

Carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA)
  • Colorectal cancer
  • Pancreatic cancer
  • Breast cancer
  • Lung cancer (especially in non-small cell cancers)
  • Gastric cancer

Prostate-specific antigen (PSA)
  • Prostate cancer
  • Benign prostatic hyperplasia
  • Prostatitis

Calcitonin (Option B ruled out)
  • Medullary thyroid cancer (both sporadic and associated with MEN 1 and MEN 2)

Alkaline phosphatase
  • Metastases to bone or liver
  • Paget disease of the bone

Placental alkaline phosphatase
  • Seminoma

Lactate dehydrogenase
  • Ovarian cancer (dysgerminoma)
  • Testicular germ cell tumours (both seminoma and nonseminoma)
  • Lymphomas
  • Ewing's sarcoma

Neuron specific enolase (NSE)
  • Neuroendocrine tumors
  • Small cell lung cancer
  • Carcinoid tumour
  • Neuroblastoma

CA 19–9

  • Pancreatic adenocarcinoma
  • Colon cancer
  • Cholangiocarcinoma

CA 15–3 and CA 27–29
  • Breast cancer

CA 125

  • Ovarian carcinoma
  • Other gynecologic malignancies

S-100 protein (S100A) and (S100B)
  • Malignant melanoma

SMRP
  • Mesothelioma

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents with a testicular mass, and a gross image of the mass is provided. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Seminoma

Explanation:

The testicular mass described, with a homogeneous, grey-white, lobulated cut surface and no signs of haemorrhage or necrosis, is most consistent with a diagnosis of Seminoma.

  • It is the most common germ cell tumour of the testis.
  • A similar presentation in the ovary is called dysgerminoma, and germinoma is present in the pineal gland.
  • Incidence: Peak incidence in the fourth decade.
  • Genetics: Seminomas contain isochromosome 12p and express OCT3/4 & NANOG.
  • Gross:
    • Seminoma has a homogeneous, grey-white, lobulated cut surface, usually devoid of haemorrhage or necrosis.
    • Generally, the tunica albuginea is not penetrated, but extension to the epididymis, spermatic cord, or scrotal sac occasionally occurs.
  • Histology of seminoma:
    • It consists of sheets of monomorphic cells arranged in poorly defined lobules, separated by fibrous septa with lymphocytic (T cell) infiltration.
    • Classic seminoma cells are large, round to polyhedral, with distinct membranes, central nuclei, and prominent nucleoli.
    • The cytoplasm is clear or watery containing glycogen.

 

Teratoma (Option A) are germ cell tumours containing tissues from all three germ layers (ectoderm, mesoderm, and endoderm). They can be benign (mature) or malignant (immature) and are commonly found in the testes, ovaries, or midline. Histologically, they present as heterogeneous masses with various tissue types (e.g., neural, muscle, epidermis, cartilage, thyroid, or intestinal tissue), often showing necrosis, calcification, or hair/teeth/bone.

 

Yolk sac tumor (Option C ) is a malignant germ cell tumour, commonly found in the testes or ovaries, especially in children and young adults. It produces alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) and appears as a solid mass with haemorrhage and necrosis, presenting in younger patients, particularly in the first two years of life. Microscopically, show a lace-like network of cuboidal or spindled cells with Schiller-Duval bodies and eosinophilic globules containing α-fetoprotein (AFP).

 

Choriocarcinoma (Option D) is a rare, highly malignant germ cell tumour, typically in the testes, ovaries, or placenta, that secretes hCG. It presents with pain, swelling, and elevated hCG levels, often with haemorrhage, necrosis, and mixed trophoblastic cells. Microscopically, it contains syncytiotrophoblasts (multinucleated, hCG-containing) and cytotrophoblasts (polygonal, clear cytoplasm).

questions.text: Which of the following is true about anaplasia?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Loss of differentiation

Explanation:

  • Anaplasia refers to the loss of differentiation of cells.
  • It is a characteristic feature of malignant tumours and is associated with the loss of normal tissue organisation and cellular features.
  • Anaplastic cells often exhibit pleomorphism, hyperchromatic nuclei, an increased nuclear-to-cytoplasmic ratio, and increased mitotic activity.

 

Loss of cohesion between cells (Option A) is a characteristic feature of malignancy.

Change of epithelium type (Option C): Metaplasia refers to the reversible change of one mature cell type to another mature cell type in response to certain stimuli or chronic irritation.

Benign and fully reversible (Option D): Anaplasia is typically seen in malignant tumours and is not fully reversible.

questions.text:
Match the given mutations with the respective cancers:


	
		
			
			A. K-RAS
			
			
			
				Myeloproliferative neoplasm
			
			
		
		
			
			B. KIT
			
			
			2. Adenocarcinoma
			
		
		
			
			C. JAK 2
			
			
			3. Pancreatic cancer
			
		
		
			
			D. ALK
			
			
			4. GIST
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) A-3, B-4, C-1, D-2

Explanation:

A. K-RAS

Pancreatic cancer

B. KIT

GIST

C. JAK 2

Myeloproliferative neoplasm

D. ALK

Adenocarcinoma

questions.text: Asbestos exposure may be associated with which of the following malignancies?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Mesothelioma

Explanation:

  • Asbestos exposure is most strongly associated with mesothelioma

Mesothelioma
  • A rare cancer arising from mesothelial cells that most commonly affects the pleura.
  • It can also affect the peritoneum, pericardium and tunica vaginalis.

Aetiology

  • Asbestos: Mesothelioma is the most specific asbestos-associated cancer
  • It is not associated with smoking

Pathology

  • Advanced pleural mesothelioma can cause extensive pleural fibrosis and thickening, making the affected side rigid and immobile.
  • Later stages fix the mediastinum in place due to pleural thickening and fibrosis.
  • The mediastinal shift is not a characteristic feature of mesothelioma.
  • M/C cytogenetic abnormality in mesothelioma: Homozygous deletion of chromosome 9p, leading to loss of tumour suppressor gene - CDKN2A.

Clinical features

  • Progressive dyspnea, chest pain, weight loss, chronic cough, hemoptysis.
  • Decreased breath sounds and dullness to percussion (due to pleural effusion or thickening).

Diagnosis

  • CT scan: Pleural thickening, effusion, or frozen hemithorax (not causing a mediastinal shift in the presence of effusion)
  • Confirmed by biopsy:
    • Epithelioid mesothelioma shows tubules, nests, or papillary structures with uniform round to oval nuclei and eosinophilic cytoplasm.
    • Sarcomatoid mesothelioma consists of spindle-shaped cells resembling fibrosarcoma.
    • Biphasic mesothelioma displays a mixture of both patterns.
  • Specific markers for mesothelioma:
    • Calretinin
    • Epithelial membrane antigen
    • Cytokeratin
    • Mesothelin

Prognosis

Poor (median survival of 9-21 months).

Mesothelioma- Gross

Mesothelioma- H & E stain

Mesothelioma- Calretinin stain


Incorrect Options:

Acute myeloid leukaemia (Option B): While there are some associations between certain environmental toxins and leukaemia, asbestos is not a significant cause of AML. Other agents like benzene are more strongly linked with leukaemia.

Hepatic angiosarcoma (Option C) is primarily associated with exposure to vinyl chloride and arsenic, not asbestos.

Skin carcinoma (Option D), particularly basal cell carcinoma and squamous cell carcinoma, is largely linked to UV radiation. Asbestos exposure is not a major risk factor for skin carcinoma.

questions.text: The following picture shows a lymph node biopsy of a 30-year-old male with cervical lymphadenopathy. The diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Hodgkin disease

Explanation:

  • The given clinical scenario and histopathological findings suggest a diagnosis of Hodgkin lymphoma, and the HPE reveals the presence of characteristic Reed-Sternberg cells.
  • Hodgkin lymphoma typically spreads in an orderly, contiguous manner from one lymph node group to the next adjacent group without skipping areas.

Histopathological variants of Hodgkin’s Lymphoma

1. Mononuclear cells
  • Single nucleus with a large, inclusion-like nucleolus with abundant cytoplasm.
  • Seen in Mixed Cellularity Hodgkin Lymphoma

2. Popcorn cells
  • Cells with multiple infolded nuclear membranes, small nucleoli, fine chromatin, and abundant pale cytoplasm.
  • Seen in Nodular lymphocyte - Predominant Hodgkin lymphoma.

3. Reed-sternberg cell

It is characterised by two nuclear lobes, large inclusion-like nucleoli, and abundant cytoplasm and is typically surrounded by lymphocytes, macrophages, and an eosinophil.

4. Lacunar cells
  • Typically found in the nodular sclerosis subtype.
  • Nuclei are more delicate, folded, or multilobate.
  • Abundant pale cytoplasm often gets disrupted during sectioning, creating an appearance where the nucleus sits in an empty space (lacuna).

 

Incorrect Options:

Acute myeloid leukaemia (AML) (Option A) is a type of cancer characterized by the rapid proliferation of abnormal myeloid blasts in the bone marrow and peripheral blood and is characterised by the presence of blasts ≥ 20% and myeloblasts with Auer rods.

Human papillomavirus (HPV) (Option C) is a sexually transmitted virus, including low-risk strains 6 & 11, causing benign genital warts, and high-risk strains 16 & 18, linked to cervical carcinoma, vulvar intraepithelial neoplasia (VIN), and vulvar carcinoma. It is characterised by the presence of enlarged, hyperchromatic nuclei with perinuclear halos (koilocytes) in the superficial layers of the epithelium.

Chronic lymphocytic leukaemia (CLL) (Option D) is a malignancy of mature B-cells not associated with lytic bone lesions or elevated calcium. It shows Smudge cells (or parachute/basket cells) due to the fragility of lymphocytes during slide preparation and convent girl appearance (a lot of homogenous, small, mature-like, round lymphocytes with scant cytoplasm).

questions.text:
Which of the following statements is true about proto-oncogenes?


	KIT has decreased expression via the tyrosine kinase signalling pathway in GIST.
	KRAS mutation is more commonly associated with small-cell lung cancer.
	ERBB2 is overexpressed in association with breast carcinomas.
	PDGFR-β has suppressed expression in colorectal cancer.
questions.solution:
• ERBB2, also known as HER2/neu, is a proto-oncogene that encodes a receptor tyrosine kinase. Amplification or overexpression of the ERBB2 gene occurs in approximately 20-30% of breast carcinomas, resulting in elevated levels of the ERBB2 protein.
  • Overexpression of ERBB2 is linked to more aggressive tumour behaviour and is a target for specific treatments, such as trastuzumab.

 

Proto-oncogene for growth factor receptor

Associated tumour

ERBB (EGFR)

ERBB2 (HER2)

  • Adenocarcinoma of lung
  • Amplification Breast carcinoma

FLT3
  • Leukaemia

RET
  • Familial medullary thyroid carcinomas
  • Multiple endocrine neoplasia 2A and B,

ALK
  • Adenocarcinoma of lung
  • Neuroblastoma
  • Certain lymphomas

KIT
  • Gastrointestinal stromal tumors, Seminomas
  • Acute Myeloid Leukaemia (AML)
  • Mastocytosis
  • Melanoma

PDGFR-B
  • Brain tumours

 

KRAS mutations (Statement 2) are more commonly associated with non-small cell lung cancer, particularly adenocarcinomas, rather than small-cell lung cancer.

 

Gastrointestinal stromal tumours (GIST) (Statement 1) are associated with activating mutations in the KIT gene, which encodes a receptor tyrosine kinase. These mutations result in increased expression and constitutive activation of KIT, playing a key role in the development of GIST.

 

PDGFR-β (Statement 4) is not suppressed in colorectal cancer. In fact, overexpression or activation of PDGFR-β has been observed in colorectal cancer.

questions.text:
Match the malignancies in Column A with the genes in Column B:

 


	
		
			
			Column A
			
			
			Column B
			
		
		
			
			1. Pleomorphic adenoma
			
			
			a. Rb
			
		
		
			
			2. Burkitt lymphoma
			
			
			b. N-MYC
			
		
		
			
			3. Neuroblastoma
			
			
			c.C-MYC
			
		
		
			
			4. Retinoblastoma
			
			
			d. PLAG1
questions.solution:
Column A

Gene

Pleomorphic adenoma

PLAG1

Burkitt lymphoma

cMyc

Neuroblastoma

nMyc

Retinoblastoma

Rb

questions.text: Neurosecretory bodies are seen in all of the following, except:
questions.solution:
Neurosecretory bodies are collections of secretory granules, typically seen in tumours that arise from neuroendocrine cells, such as medullary thyroid carcinoma, pituitary adenoma, and paraganglioma. However, adrenal cortical tumours originate from the adrenal cortex and do not typically contain neurosecretory bodies.

 

Adrenocortical Neoplasms:

  • It causes various forms of hyperadrenalism, including both adenomas and carcinomas.
  • These tumours are common in adults, with carcinomas being more prevalent in children.
  • Li-Fraumeni syndrome (due to TP53 mutations) and Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome (linked to IGF-2 overexpression) increase the risk for adrenocortical carcinoma.

 

Types of Adrenocortical Neoplasms:

  • Functional adenomas:
    • It often causes hyperaldosteronism or Cushing syndrome, with virilizing neoplasms usually being carcinomas.
    • Some neoplasms do not secrete hormones; their functionality is assessed via clinical evaluation and hormone testing.
  • Nonfunctional Adenomas:
    • Usually asymptomatic, often detected incidentally.
    • Small, well-circumscribed lesions (up to 2.5 cm) have a normal surrounding adrenal cortex and are yellow-brown due to lipid content.
    • Microscopically, they resemble normal adrenal cortex cells with minimal mitotic activity and a Ki-67 index < 5%.
  • Adrenocortical Carcinomas:
    • Rare and typically more functional than adenomas, often associated with virilism and other hyperadrenalism symptoms.
    • These large, invasive tumours (>20 cm) can invade the adrenal vein, vena cava, and lymphatics, with frequent metastases to regional nodes and distant organs.
    • Survival rates are low, with a median of 2 years.

 

Neuroendocrine tumors:

  • Carcinoid tumor
  • Pituitary adenoma (Option B)
  • Pancreatic Neuroendocrine Tumor (PanNET)
  • Medullary Thyroid Carcinoma (MTC) (Option A)
  • Pheochromocytoma
  • Paraganglioma (Option C)
  • Small Cell Lung Cancer (SCLC)
  • Large Cell Neuroendocrine Carcinoma (LCNEC)
  • Neuroblastoma

questions.text:
Match the following microscopic appearance and the respective tumour in which they are seen

 


	
		
			
			Microscopic appearance
			
			
			Tumor
			
		
		
			
			1. Schiller Duval bodies
			
			
			a. Krukenberg tumor
			
		
		
			
			2. Presence of teeth, hair, etc
			
			
			B.  Granulosa cell tumor
			
		
		
			
			3. Signet ring cells
			
			
			C. Yolk sac tumour
			
		
		
			
			4. Call-Exner bodies
			
			
			d. Teratoma
questions.solution:
Microscopic Appearance

Tumor

Schiller Duval bodies

Yolk sac tumour

Presence of teeth, hair, etc.

Teratoma

Signet ring cells

Kruckenberg tumor

Call-Exner bodies

Granulosa cell tumor

 

Yolk Sac tumour or endodermal sinus tumour:

  • Common in infants and children up to 3 years old.
  • Morphology:
    • Gross: Solid grey-white with a gelatinous or mucoid appearance.
    • Microscopy:

50% of the tumours show a lace-like network of medium-sized cuboidal, flattened, or spindled cells with endodermal sinuses (Schiller-Duval or glomerular bodies).

  • Eosinophilic, hyaline-like globules containing α-fetoprotein (AFP) and α1-antitrypsin are present.

 

Granulosa cell tumour:

  • Originates from granulosa cells of the ovarian follicle.
  • Occurs in postmenopausal women (adult type) or at any age (juvenile type)
  • Juvenile cases may present with precocious sexual development, while adults may experience abnormal uterine bleeding and endometrial hyperplasia (which can lead to carcinoma)
  • Microscopically, Call-Exner bodies and coffee bean nuclei are observed
  • Elevated inhibin levels, CD99 positivity, and FOXL2 mutations are seen.

Signet ring cells:

  • They are typically associated with Krukenberg tumours, which are metastases of diffuse gastric carcinoma to the ovaries.
  • Grossly, Krukenberg tumours often present with bilateral, symmetric ovarian enlargement with an intact capsule.
  • Signet ring cells contain mucin that pushes the nucleus to the periphery, creating a "signet ring" appearance.

Teratoma: Teratomas in adult males are typically large, ranging from 5 to 10 cm in diameter, with a heterogeneous appearance consisting of various organoid structures, such as neural tissue, muscle, epidermis, cartilage, thyroid gland, or intestinal wall.

 

  • These elements may be mature or immature, sharing histologic features with fetal or embryonic tissue.
  • Microscopically, these structures are embedded in a fibrous or myxoid stroma.

questions.text: The type of cancer that rarely spreads through the lymphatic system is:
questions.solution:
BCC (basal cell carcinoma) is typically localized, grows slowly, and has a low metastasis potential. It rarely spreads to lymph nodes or distant organs, making it less likely to disseminate than SCC (Squamous Cell Carcinoma), MCC (Merkel Cell Carcinoma), or malignant melanoma.

 

Metastasis (distant spread)

  • All cancers are going to show metastasis except:
    • BCC (Basal cell carcinoma / Rodent's ulcer)
    • Brain Tumor/Glioma
  • Types of metastatic spread:
    • Hematogenous spread
    • Lymphatic spread
    • Transcoelomic spread
    • Direct seeding of body cavities or surfaces

 

Hematogenous spread

Lymphatic spread

Transcoelomic spread

Veins are more prone to invasion than arteries due to their thinner walls.

Tumours use existing lymphatic vessels at their margins. Follows natural routes of lymphatic drainage.

Tumour invades the serosal wall of the coelomic cavity, releasing tumour fragments into coelomic fluid, which is implanted elsewhere in the body cavity.

Seen in most of the sarcomas.

Seen in most carcinomas.

Seen in Krukenberg tumour in the ovary due to metastasis from gastric carcinoma to the ovary.

Exceptions:

  • Synovial sarcoma
  • Rhabdomyosarcoma


*These tumours are spread by the lymphatic route.

Exceptions:

  • HCC
  • RCC
  • Follicular carcinoma of the thyroid
  • Choriocarcinoma


*These tumours are spread by a hematogenous route.

  

 

Direct Seeding of Body Cavities or Surfaces:

  • It occurs when malignant neoplasms spread to anatomical spaces that lack physical barriers, such as the peritoneal cavity (more commonly), but they can also affect other body cavities, such as the pleural, pericardial, subarachnoid, and joint spaces.
  • Examples include:
  1. Pseudomyxoma peritonei is characterized by the presence of a gelatinous neoplastic mass filling the peritoneal cavity arising from the rupture of mucus-secreting appendiceal (most common cause) or ovarian carcinomas.
  2. Gastric carcinoma can spread to the distal end of the peritoneal cavity (Pouch of Douglas) and is known as the ‘Blummer shelf.’
  3. Medulloblastoma from the cerebellum spreads to the spinal cord by ‘Drop metastasis.’

 

Squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) (Option A) arises from squamous cells in the outermost skin layer and can occur in the skin, lips, mouth, throat, esophagus, lungs, and other organs. It has a higher metastatic potential than basal cell carcinoma, often spreading via the lymphatic route.


 

Merkel cell carcinoma (MCC) (Option B) is a rare, aggressive skin cancer arising from touch-sensitive Merkel cells. It typically occurs on sun-exposed areas like the head, neck, and arms and has a high tendency to spread via the lymphatic system.


 

Malignant melanoma (Option D) is an aggressive skin cancer arising from melanocytes, with a high potential for lymphatic and hematogenous metastasis to organs like the liver, lungs, brain, and bones. Early detection and treatment are crucial for better outcomes.

questions.text: A 70-year-old male comes with complaints of hip pain. An X-ray of the hip shows lytic lesions and elevated serum calcium levels. Bone marrow plasma cells are 42%, and the cells seen are given in the image below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Multiple myeloma

Explanation:

  • Multiple myeloma is characterised by malignant plasma cell proliferation in the bone marrow, leading to lytic bone lesions and elevated serum calcium levels (due to bone resorption). The presence of plasma cells further supports the diagnosis.

Bone Marrow Biopsy Findings of Multiple Myeloma:

  • Increased number of plasma cells in the marrow, often >30% of cellularity.
  • Plasma cells may infiltrate the interstitium subtly or completely replace normal elements.
  • HPE:
    • Eccentric nucleus with perinuclear clearing (prominent Golgi) and abundant basophilic cytoplasm.
  • Normal-appearing plasma cells, plasmablasts with vesicular nuclear chromatin and prominent single nucleolus, or bizarre, multinucleated cells may predominate.
  • Other Cytologic Variants (due to dysregulated Ig synthesis and secretion):
    • Flame cells: Fiery red cytoplasm.
    • Mott cells: Contain multiple grapelike cytoplasmic droplets.
  • Inclusions:
    • Russell bodies: Globular cytoplasmic inclusions.
    • Dutcher bodies: Globular nuclear inclusions.


Incorrect Options:

CLL (Option B) is a malignancy of mature B-cells, not associated with lytic bone lesions or elevated calcium. It shows Smudge cells (or parachute/basket cells) due to the fragility of lymphocytes during slide preparation and convent girl appearance (a lot of homogenous, small, mature-like, round lymphocytes with scant cytoplasm).

ALL (Option C) affects immature lymphocytes and typically presents with other hematologic symptoms, not lytic bone lesions and elevated calcium. It shows Lymphoblasts in bone marrow >=20%, Cytoplasmic vacuolations, fat (Oil Red O Positive) and hand mirror-shaped cells.

CML (Option D) is a myeloproliferative disorder that primarily affects granulocytes and is not associated with plasma cells or lytic bone lesions. It presents with Leukocytosis with cell types including Neutrophils (multilobed nucleus), metamyelocytes (indented nucleus), myelocytes (D-shaped nucleus), and eosinophils (orange cells)

  • College girl/garden party appearance: Due to the variety of cell appearances
  • Shift to the Left: Presence of immature cell types, mainly immature neutrophils, in the blood.

questions.text: Anaplasia refers to:

choices.text: Variation in cell size and shape
Replacement of one type of cell by other

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Lack of differentiation:

  • Anaplasia is characterized by the loss of normal cellular differentiation, i.e., the tumor cells do not resemble the parent tissue cells they originated from.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Variation in cell size and shape: Pleomorphism refers to the presence of cells with different sizes and shapes within a tumor.

Option C - Replacement of one type of cell by another: Metaplasia refers to the reversible change of one mature cell type to another mature cell type in response to certain stimuli or chronic irritation.

Option D - Disordered arrangement of tumor cells: The disordered arrangement of tumor cells is known as architectural disorder or loss of normal tissue architecture, which is often observed in malignant tumors.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about anaplasia?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Loss of differentiation:

  • Anaplasia refers to the loss of differentiation of cells.
  • It is a characteristic feature of malignant tumors and is associated with the loss of normal tissue organization and cellular features.
  • Anaplastic cells often exhibit pleomorphism, hyperchromatic nuclei, an increased nuclear-to-cytoplasmic ratio, and increased mitotic activity.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Loss of cohesion between cells: Loss of cohesion between cells is a characteristic feature of malignancy.

Option C - Change of epithelium type: Metaplasia refers to the reversible change of one mature cell type to another mature cell type in response to certain stimuli or chronic irritation.

Option D - Benign and fully reversible: Anaplasia is typically seen in malignant tumors and is not fully reversible.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a small round blue cell tumor?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Hemangioblastoma:

  • Hemangioblastoma is not a small round blue cell tumor.
  • It is a rare, benign tumor that arises from the blood vessels in the central nervous system.
  • Histologically, it is characterized by abundant blood vessels and stromal cells.
  • It is commonly associated with von Hippel-Lindau disease, an inherited condition that predisposes individuals to the development of various tumors.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Ewing's sarcoma:

  • Ewing's sarcoma is a malignant tumor that predominantly affects children and young adults.
  • It is characterized by small round blue cells with a high nuclear-to-cytoplasmic ratio.
  • It commonly arises in the bones, but it can also occur in soft tissues.
  • Ewing's sarcoma often presents with localized pain and swelling and can metastasize to other sites.

Option C - Retinoblastoma:

  • Retinoblastoma is a malignant tumor that develops in the retina of the eye.
  • It primarily affects children and can occur unilaterally or bilaterally.
  • Retinoblastoma is characterized by small round blue cells and can cause leukocoria and visual disturbances.
  • It is associated with mutations in the RB1 gene.

Option D - Neuroblastoma:

  • Neuroblastoma is a malignant tumor that arises from primitive nerve cells, typically in the adrenal glands or along the sympathetic nervous system.
  • It is the most common extracranial solid tumor in children.
  • Neuroblastoma is composed of small round blue cells and can present with various signs and symptoms, including abdominal mass, bone pain, and neurologic changes.

questions.text: Which of the following does not fall under the provisional entity in the WHO 2016 classification of hematolymphoid tumours?

choices.text: Natural Killer cell lymphoblastic leukemia / lymphoma
Acute myeloid leukemia with RUNX1 mutation

questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Splenic B-cell lymphoma / leukemia:

  • In the WHO 2016 classification of hematolymphoid tumors, provisional entity refers to a category that includes certain rare or less well-characterized entities where further research and clinical experience are needed to determine their precise classification and clinical significance.
  • This is not included as a provisional entity. It has its own classification within the WHO classification of lymphoid neoplasms.

Incorrect Options:

  • Option A, B, and C are included as a provisional entity in the WHO 2016 classification of hematolymphoid tumors.

questions.text: Which of the following proto-oncogenes is not implicated in carcinoma of the thyroid??
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - p53:

  • p53 is not implicated in carcinoma of the thyroid.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - RAS: Mutations in the RAS proto-oncogene, particularly the HRAS and KRAS isoforms, are found in thyroid cancer.

Option B - RET: Mutations in RET are associated with multiple endocrine neoplasia type 2 (MEN2) syndromes, which include medullary thyroid carcinoma.

Option C - BRAF: Mutations in the BRAF proto-oncogene, particularly the V600E mutation, are found in papillary thyroid carcinoma.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common brain tumor seen in children?
questions.solution:
Correct option A: Medulloblastoma:

  • Medulloblastoma is the most common brain tumors seen in children.
  • It typically occurs in the cerebellum, which is the part of the brain responsible for coordination and balance.
  • Medulloblastomas are fast-growing tumors that often present with symptoms such as headaches, vomiting, unsteadiness, and problems with motor coordination.
  • Treatment typically involves a combination of surgery, radiation therapy, and chemotherapy.

Incorrect options: Options B, C, and D are incorrect.

questions.text: Which of the following components is typically not included in immunohistochemistry for acute lymphoblastic leukemia?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Cytokeratin:

  • Cytokeratins are a group of proteins that are primarily found in epithelial cells, which line the surfaces and cavities of the body.
  • They are not specific markers for lymphoid cells and are not typically used in the diagnosis of acute lymphoblastic leukemia.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - TdT:

  • Tdt is an enzyme that is typically present in the early stages of lymphoid cell development.
  • It is not found in mature lymphocytes but is expressed in lymphoblasts, which are the immature precursor cells in ALL.
  • Tdt is commonly used as a marker to identify and confirm the presence of lymphoblasts in ALL.
  • Tdt-positive staining indicates the presence of immature lymphoid cells, which is a characteristic feature of ALL.

Option B - CD1a:

  • CD1a is a cell surface marker that is predominantly expressed on Langerhans cells, which are specialized immune cells found in the skin and mucosal tissues.
  • In the context of immunohistochemistry for ALL, CD1a is used to differentiate T-cell ALL (which is CD1a-positive) from B-cell ALL (which is CD1a-negative).

Option C - CD3:

  • CD3 is a complex of proteins that is present on the surface of mature T lymphocytes.
  • In the context of immunohistochemistry for ALL, CD3 is used to detect T-cell ALL, as the malignant cells in this subtype express CD3 on their surface.
  • CD3-positive staining helps confirm the T-cell lineage of the leukemia cells.

questions.text: NARP syndrome belongs to:
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Mitochondrial function disorder:

  • NARP syndrome is caused by mutations in the mitochondrial DNA, specifically in the ATPase 6 gene.
  • Mitochondrial function disorders involve defects in the mitochondria, which are responsible for producing energy in the form of ATP through oxidative phosphorylation.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, C, and D are incorrect.

questions.text: How would you distinguish between a thymoma and ALL when presented with a mediastinal mass?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Cytokeratin:

  • Cytokeratins are intermediate filaments found in epithelial cells.
  • Thymomas are tumors of thymic epithelial cells and express cytokeratin markers.
  • ALL is a lymphoid malignancy and does not express cytokeratins.

Incorrect Options:

  • Options A, B, and C are incorrect.

questions.text: The mutations / changes that convert proto-oncogene to oncogene include all except:
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Enhancer deletion:

  • Enhancer deletion is not a mechanism that directly converts a proto-oncogene to an oncogene.
  • Enhancers are regulatory DNA sequences that enhance the transcription of genes.
  • While enhancer mutations can contribute to gene dysregulation, they do not directly convert a proto-oncogene to an oncogene.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Promoter insertion:

  • Promoter insertion is a genetic alteration that can convert a proto-oncogene to an oncogene.
  • When a promoter sequence is inserted near a proto-oncogene, it can lead to increased and unregulated expression of the gene, promoting cell growth and division.

Option C - Gene amplification:

  • Gene amplification refers to an increase in the number of copies of a specific gene.
  • If a proto-oncogene undergoes amplification, it results in an increased dosage of the gene product, leading to abnormal cell proliferation and potentially converting it to an oncogene.

Option D - Point mutation:

  • Point mutations, which are single nucleotide changes in the DNA sequence, can convert a proto-oncogene to an oncogene.
  • Point mutations can result in altered protein function, increased protein stability, or constitutive activation of signalling pathways, promoting uncontrolled cell growth and division.
